revision.text:
{{Infobox comedian |name = Neal Brennan |image = Neal Brennan with paper face.jpg |image_size = 225px |caption = Brennan in 2012 |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1973|10|19}}<ref name=NYT/> |birth_name = |birth_place = [[Villanova, Pennsylvania]], U.S. |medium = [[Stand-up comedy|Stand-up]], [[television]], [[film]] |active = 1995–present |genre = [[Observational comedy]], [[surreal humor]], [[sketch comedy]], [[black comedy]], [[blue comedy]], [[satire]] |subject = [[American politics]], [[American culture]], [[popular culture|pop culture]], [[racism]], [[race relations]], [[recreational drug use]], [[human sexuality]], [[morality]] |notable_work = ''[[Chappelle's Show]]'' |website = {{URL|nealbrennan.com}} }} '''Neal Brennan''' (born October 19, 1973)<ref name=NYT>{{cite news|title=Novice Director, a Veteran of Comedy|first=Josh|last=Eells|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/09/movies/09eels.html?_r=1|newspaper=New York Times|date=August 7, 2009|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref><ref name=CBS>{{cite news|title=Chappelle's Trip To The Top|first=Rebecca|last=Leung|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2005/05/27/60ii/main698261.shtml|newspaper=CBS News|date=February 11, 2009|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref><ref name=SANDIEGO>{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiego.com/articles/2011-06-22/obama-twitter-and-pokez-neal-brennan-sketch-comedy-diet|title=Obama, Twitter and Pokez: The Neal Brennan Sketch Comedy Diet|last=Downs|first=Gordon|date=June 22, 2011|work=SanDiego.com|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref> is an American comedian, writer, producer, and director.
He is known for co-creating and co-writing the [[Comedy Central]] series ''[[Chappelle's Show]]'' with [[Dave Chappelle]].<ref name=VANSUN>{{cite news|title=ComedyFest: Neal Brennan enters Vancouver laughing|first=Mike|last=Hager|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/entertainment/movie-guide/ComedyFest+Neal+Brennan+enters+Vancouver+laughing/6206681/story.html|newspaper=Vancouver Sun|date=February 24, 2012|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name=MSNBC>{{cite news|title=Dave Chappelle inks $50 million deal|first=Andrew|last=Wallenstein|url=http://msnbc.msn.com/id/5591225/site/todayshow/ns/today-entertainment/t/dave-chappelle-inks-million-deal/#.T0xoq3lc-So|newspaper=MSNBC|date=August 3, 2004|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref><ref name=AUSTIN>{{cite news|title=Saturday Interview - Neal Brennan|first=Chase|last=Hoffberger|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2011-11-04/saturday-interview-neal-brennan/|newspaper=Austin Chronicle|date=November 4, 2011|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref> By the end of the second season, it was ranked as the most popular Comedy Central show. It premiered in January 2003 and continued until 2006.
==Early life== Brennan grew up in [[Villanova, Pennsylvania]], near [[Philadelphia]],<ref name="NYT"/><ref>{{Cite podcast|url=http://www.nerdist.com/2011/11/you-made-it-weird-7-neal-brennan/|title=You Made It Weird: Neal Brennan|website=nerdist.com|publisher=Nerdist Industries|host=[[Pete Holmes|Holmes, Pete]]|date=November 23, 2011|time=19:07|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref> and lived from 1978 to 1986 in [[Wilmette, Illinois]].<ref name=IFC>{{cite web|url=http://www.ifc.com/fix/2011/11/neal-brennan-comedy-interview|title=Neal Brennan talks about his influences, writing race-sensitive material and the state of contemporary comedy|date=November 30, 2011|website=IFC.com|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref><ref name=CHICAGONOW1>{{cite news|title=Just for Laughs exclusive - Neal Brennan interview|first=Scott|last=King|url=http://www.chicagonow.com/class-act-comedy/2011/06/just-for-laughs-exclusive-neal-brennan-interview/|newspaper=Chicago Now|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=June 14, 2011|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref> He was born into an [[Irish Catholic]] family and is the youngest of 10 children.<ref name=NYT/><ref name=IFC/><ref name=HUMORCODE>{{cite web|url=http://humorcode.com/2012/02/14/humor-code-q-a-unabridged-neal-brennan-on-life-after-chappelles-show-failed-irish-jokes-and-feeding-the-comedy-baby/|title=Humor Code Q & A (Unabridged): Neal Brennan on Life after Chappelle’s Show, Failed Irish Jokes and Feeding the Comedy Baby|last=McGraw|first=Dr. Peter|author2=Warner, Joel|date=February 14, 2012|work=humorcode.com|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref> According to Brennan, his father's side of the family was funny, as were his five older brothers.<ref name=NYT/><ref name=HUMORCODE/> Brennan said that he realized he was funny and liked comedy at about 8 or 9 years of age; he was already performing planned material for his classmates in a style that emulated comics [[Richard Lewis (comedian)|Richard Lewis]], [[Jerry Seinfeld]] and [[David Brenner]].<ref name=CAREER>{{cite web|url=http://thecareercookbook.com/article.php?article_id=2|title=Neal Brennan|last=Maniaci|first=Paul|date=September 2, 2006|work=thecareercookbook.com|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref> He also watched a large amount of comedy on TV during his high school years, often staying up late to watch ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]'' and ''[[The Arsenio Hall Show]]''.<ref name=CAREER/>
Brennan's older brother [[Kevin Brennan (comedian)|Kevin]] became a comedian and writer who started doing [[stand-up comedy]] while Neal was still in [[high school]].<ref name=CHICAGONOW1/> Neal attended Kevin's performances at [[The Improv]] in [[New York City]] on weekends,<ref name=NYT/> where he would meet comedians such as [[Ray Romano]], [[Dave Attell]], [[Mike Royce]] and [[David Juskow]].<ref name=CAREER/><ref name=ALIVE/> Brennan said in an interview with [[IFC (U.S. TV channel)|Independent Film Channel]] (IFC) that, after watching his brother do stand-up, he realized it was possible to make a living in comedy.<ref name=IFC/>
Brennan moved to New York to attend film school at [[NYU]], but he dropped out after a year.<ref name=CAREER/><ref name=CHICAGONOW1/><ref name=ALIVE>{{cite news|title=Comedy Q&A: Neal Brennan|first=Jesse|last=Tigges|url=http://www.columbusalive.com/content/stories/2011/07/13/comedy-qa-neal-brennan.html|newspaper=Columbus Alive!|date=July 13, 2011|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref> He began as a doorman at the now-defunct Boston Comedy Club in [[Greenwich Village]] where he met [[Dave Chappelle]], a frequent performer.<ref name="CBS"/><ref name=NYT2/> The two became friends and Brennan would often pitch jokes to Chappelle.<ref name=CHICAGONOW1/><ref name=NYT2/> Brennan also shared an apartment with comedian [[Jay Mohr]] while living in New York.<ref name=NYT/>
After six months of working as a doorman at the Boston Comedy Club, in 1992, Brennan first performed stand-up at 18 years of age.<ref name="SANDIEGO"/> He later recounted: "I got no laughs;" he didn't perform stand-up again until 1997.<ref name=SANDIEGO/> Brennan also wrote for ''[[The Source (magazine)|The Source]]'' magazine in 1992.<ref name=IFC/><ref>{{Cite podcast|url=http://www.nerdist.com/2011/11/you-made-it-weird-7-neal-brennan/|title=You Made It Weird: Neal Brennan|website=nerdist.com|publisher=Nerdist Industries|host=Holmes, Pete|date=November 23, 2011|time=56:09|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref>
==Career== [[File:Neal Brennan.jpg|thumb|Brennan on stage]] In the mid-1990s, Brennan moved to [[Los Angeles]]. In 1995, he became a writer for the dating show, ''[[Singled Out]],'' hosted by [[Jenny McCarthy]] and [[Chris Hardwick]].<ref name=CAREER/><ref name=CHICAGONOW1/> This was followed by writing jobs for the game show ''[[Bzzz!]]'' in 1996, the [[sketch comedy]]-[[variety show]] ''[[All That]]'' from 1996 to 1997, and the teen sitcom ''[[Kenan & Kel]]'' in 1997.<ref name=CAREER/><ref name=CHICAGONOW1/><ref name=IMDB>{{IMDb name|0107366|Neal Brennan}}</ref><ref>{{cite podcast|url=http://blog.joerogan.net/archives/4611|title=The Joe Rogan Experience, Episode #205|website=joerogan.net|host=Rogan, Joe|date=April 12, 2012|time=1:47:54|accessdate=April 20, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120417041922/http://blog.joerogan.net/archives/4611|archivedate=April 17, 2012|df=}}</ref>
In 1997, Brennan and Chappelle collaborated for the first time on the screenplay for the film ''[[Half Baked]]''.<ref name=CAREER/><ref name=NYT2>{{cite news|title=A Comic Who Won't Hold Back; Nothing Is Out of Bounds For Dave Chappelle's Show|first=Lola|last=Ogunnaike|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/18/arts/a-comic-who-won-t-hold-back-nothing-is-out-of-bounds-for-dave-chappelle-s-show.html?pagewanted=3&src=pm|newspaper=New York Times|date=February 18, 2004|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref> The film was released in January 1998 and starred Chappelle, [[Jim Breuer]], [[Harland Williams]] and [[Guillermo Díaz (actor)|Guillermo Díaz]].<ref name=CAREER/><ref name=NYT3>{{cite news|title=Half Baked (1998) FILM REVIEW; Marijuana Moments, Many of Them|first=Lola|last=Ogunnaike|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9B02E0D91738F934A25752C0A96E958260|newspaper=New York Times|date=January 18, 1998|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref> ''Half Baked'' was a commercial failure and received mainly negative reviews but has become a cult classic.<ref name=NYT/><ref name=BUZZBIN>{{cite web|url=http://www.buzzbinmagazine.com/home/2011/07/18/taking-the-leap-with-neal-brennan/|title=Taking the Leap with Neal Brennan|last=Flannigan|first=W.|date=July 18, 2011|work=buzzbinmagazine.com|accessdate=April 20, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509074949/http://www.buzzbinmagazine.com/home/2011/07/18/taking-the-leap-with-neal-brennan/|archivedate=May 9, 2012|df=}}</ref><ref name=VARIETY>{{cite news|title=Half Baked|first=Brendan|last=Kelly|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117436781?refcatid=31|newspaper=Variety|date=January 19, 1998|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref>
In a 2006 interview, Brennan referred to the period of the film's release as "probably the worst year of my life, creatively and personally."<ref name=CAREER/> In an interview that same year on ''[[Inside the Actor's Studio]]'', Chappelle recounted how he and Brennan lost touch with each other after the release of ''Half Baked'', saying that it was "like leaving a crime scene".<ref>{{cite episode|title=Dave Chappelle|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=84NjYRTHpfU| accessdate=April 20, 2012|series=Inside the Actors Studio|airdate=February 12, 2006|time=55:00}}</ref>
===''Chappelle's Show''=== Four years later, Brennan and Chappelle came together to co-create, co-write and co-[[Executive producer|executive produce]] the eponymous [[sketch comedy]] ''[[Chappelle's Show]]'', which premiered in January 2003.<ref name=NYT/><ref name=MSNBC/><ref name=NYT2/> Brennan said that he and Chappelle read the book ''Live from New York: An Uncensored History of Saturday Night Live'' (2002), by [[Tom Shales]] when they started writing sketches for the show, and found the book very helpful.<ref name=CHICAGONOW2>{{cite news|title=What really happened with Chappelle's Show and more: Neal Brennan interview Part 2|first=Scott|last=King|url=http://www.chicagonow.com/class-act-comedy/2011/06/what-really-happened-with-chappelles-show-and-more-neal-brennan-interview-part-2/|newspaper=Chicago Now|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=June 16, 2011|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref> The duo wrote the show's sketches with minimal outside help<ref name=SANDIEGO/><ref name=EW>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1058529,00.html|title=Half-Baked Theories|last=Susman|first=Gary|date=May 6, 2005|work=EW.com|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref> and agreed never to divulge who was responsible for writing which sketch.<ref name=VANSUN/><ref>{{cite podcast|url=http://blog.joerogan.net/archives/3195|title=The Joe Rogan Experience, Episode #114|website=joerogan.net|host=Rogan, Joe|date=June 14, 2011|time=1:15:22|accessdate=April 20, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120505164519/http://blog.joerogan.net/archives/3195|archivedate=May 5, 2012|df=}}</ref>
Brennan directed some sketches in the show's second season, including the sketch featuring Chappelle as musician [[Rick James]].<ref name=NYT/><ref name=CAREER/><ref name=IMDB/> Brennan was nominated for three [[Emmy Award]]s in 2004 for his work on the show as a director, writer and producer.<ref name=TAHOE>{{cite news|title='Chappelle's Show'writer debuts at Tahoe Improv|first=Howie|last=Nave|url=http://www.tahoedailytribune.com/article/20120321/NEWS/120329974/1017&parentprofile=1058|newspaper=Tahoe Daily Tribune|date=March 21, 2012|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{IMDb title|0353049|Awards for "Chappelle's Show"}}</ref> By the end of its second season, ''Chappelle's Show'' was Comedy Central's highest-rated program.<ref name=BEAST>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2005/05/15/fears-of-a-clown.html|title=Fears of a Clown|last=Gordon|first=Devin|date=May 15, 2005|work=[[The Daily Beast]]|accessdate=April 20, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120118153307/http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2005/05/15/fears-of-a-clown.html|archivedate=January 18, 2012|df=}}</ref>
Members of the musical group [[The Roots]] worked as music directors on the second and third seasons of the show.<ref name=HUFFPO>{{cite news|title=The Roots are ready to rock, rap, jazz and even disco the set of Late Night with Jimmy Fallon|first=Danny|last=Gallagher |url=http://www.chicagonow.com/class-act-comedy/2011/06/just-for-laughs-exclusive-neal-brennan-interview/|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=February 27, 2009|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref><ref name=SEATTLEPI>{{cite news|title=The Roots: House-band gig 'enabled us to survive'|first=Jake|last=Coyle|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/ae/music/article/The-Roots-House-band-gig-enabled-us-to-survive-1300977.php|newspaper=SeattlePi|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Hearst Communications|date=February 24, 2009|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref> Brennan later recommended the band to [[Jimmy Fallon]] as his [[house band]] on ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]''.<ref name=HUFFPO/><ref name=SEATTLEPI/><ref name=TAMPA>{{cite news|title=Hip-hop band the Roots prepares for TV gig on 'Late Night With Jimmy Fallon'|first=Eric|last=Deggans|url=http://www.tampabay.com/features/media/article979876.ece|newspaper=Tampa Bay Times|date=March 1, 2009|accessdate=April 20, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121212062045/http://www.tampabay.com/features/media/article979876.ece|archivedate=December 12, 2012|df=}}</ref>
''Chappelle's Show'' was doing well and Chappelle had signed a $50 million deal in 2004 to produce two more seasons,<ref name=CBS/><ref name=MSNBC/><ref name=EW/><ref name=OPRAH>{{cite episode|title=Chappelle's Story|url=http://www.oprah.com/oprahshow/Chappelles-Story|accessdate=April 20, 2012|series=The Oprah Winfrey Show|airdate=February 9, 2006}}</ref> but he abruptly left the show in April 2005 prior to the premiere of the show's third season.<ref name=CBS/><ref name=EW/><ref name="OPRAH"/> He left without warning Brennan or others of the show's crew.<ref name=CHICAGONOW2/><ref name=EW/><ref name=LATIMES/><ref name=NPR>{{Cite episode|title=Comedian Chappelle Surfaces in 'Time'|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4653985|accessdate=April 20, 2012|series=All Things Considered|serieslink=All Things Considered|credits=Presenter: [[Michele Norris]]|network=National Public Radio|date=May 16, 2005}}</ref> As a result, the premiere of season three was delayed; Brennan compiled the remaining sketches and aired them in July 2006 as the "[[List of Chappelle's Show episodes#Season 3 ("The Lost Episodes"): 2006|lost episodes]]."<ref name=LATIMES>{{cite news|title=Chappelle returns, sort of|first=David|last=Bauder|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/jul/08/entertainment/et-chappelle8|newspaper=Associated Press|date=July 8, 2006|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref><ref name=NYT4>{{cite news|title=The Long-Awaited, Albeit Brief, Return of Dave Chappelle|first=Lola|last=Ogunnaike|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/06/arts/television/06dave.html?_r=1|newspaper=New York Times|date=July 6, 2006|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref>
===2006 to present=== In 2006, Brennan directed and co-wrote the [[Television film|made-for-TV movie]] ''[[Totally Awesome]]''.<ref name=TAHOE/><ref name=LAIST>{{cite news|title=LAist Interview: Neal Brennan|first=Tim|last=Hammer|url=http://laist.com/2007/10/17/laist_interview_52.php|newspaper=LAist|date=October 7, 2007|accessdate=April 20, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090717015205/http://laist.com/2007/10/17/laist_interview_52.php|archivedate=July 17, 2009|df=}}</ref> Brennan directed the 2009 film ''[[The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard|The Goods]]'' starring [[Jeremy Piven]].<ref name=CHICAGONOW1/><ref name=TAHOE/> In 2011, he directed a series of commercials for the [[ESPY Award|ESPYS]].<ref name=SANDIEGO/><ref name=ALIVE/>
As an actor, Brennan had small roles in the films ''[[Half Baked]]'' and ''[[Get Him to the Greek]];'' he also appeared in various sketches on ''[[Chappelle's Show]]''.<ref name=IMDB/> Brennan has also written comedy material for the [[83rd Academy Awards]], as well as for [[Seth Meyers]]' speech at the [[White House Correspondents' Association#White House Correspondents' Dinner|White House Correspondents' Dinner]] in 2011.<ref name=CHICAGONOW1/><ref name=WIRED>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/underwire/2012/03/humor-code-neal-brennan/|title=The Humor Code: Neal Brennan on 'Comedic Polymaths' and the Future of Funny|last=Warner|first=Joel|author2=McGraw, Peter|date=March 1, 2012|work=Wired.com|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref>
Brennan continues to perform stand-up regularly in the Los Angeles area as well as nationally.<ref name=WIRED/><ref name=ARC>{{cite news|title=Half Baked|first=Trevor|last=Horn|author2=Frields, Philip|url=http://www.arcurrent.com/arts-culture/2011/10/26/qa-with-%E2%80%98chappelles-show%E2%80%99-co-creator-neal-brennan/|newspaper=American River Current|date=October 26, 2011|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref> He has also appeared on ''[[Last Call with Carson Daly]]'', ''Late Night with Jimmy Fallon'', ''[[Lopez Tonight]]'', and ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]''.<ref name=CHICAGONOW1/><ref name=TAHOE/><ref>[http://teamcoco.com/video/comedian-neal-brennan Video of Neal Brennan on ''Conan''], September 27, 2011</ref>
In 2011, Brennan, comedian [[Moshe Kasher]], and DJ Douggpound ([[Doug Lussenhop]] of ''[[Tim and Eric Nite Live!]]''), started a podcast called ''The Champs''.<ref name=SANDIEGO2>{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiego.com/articles/2011-07-20/living-edge-moshe-kasher |title=Living On The Edge with Moshe Kasher|last=Downs|first=Gordon|date=July 20, 2011|work=SanDiego.com|accessdate=April 20, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite podcast|url=http://blog.joerogan.net/archives/3443|title=The Joe Rogan Experience, Episode #131|website=joerogan.net|host=Rogan, Joe|date=August 17, 2011|time=1:49:07|accessdate=April 20, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120505173329/http://blog.joerogan.net/archives/3443|archivedate=May 5, 2012|df=}}</ref> Kasher said of the podcast: "It's Doug dropping sound effects and beats over me and Neal kind of hosting an hour of ridiculous chat. We have a rotating [[Black people|black]] guy guest, there's a different black guest every week."<ref name=SANDIEGO2/> Guests on the show have included actor/comedians [[Wayne Brady]], [[Chris Rock]], [[Mario Joyner]], Shawn and Marlon [[Wayans]], and [[David Alan Grier]], [[Pornographic film|adult film]] star [[Lexington Steele]], rapper [[Too $hort]], and professional basketball player [[Blake Griffin]]. The show has strayed from its guest format on occasion with guests such as comedian and actor [[Bobby Lee]], former pornographic actress [[Sasha Grey]], former Major League Baseball player [[Jose Canseco]] and comedian/actor [[Aziz Ansari]]. In 2014 ''The Champs'' was named "Best Podcast" as part of ''[[LA Weekly]]''{{'s}} "Best of L.A." issue.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Best Podcast Los Angeles 2014 — The Champs|url=http://www.laweekly.com/los-angeles/best-podcast/BestOf?oid=5108130|journal=LA Weekly|date=October 2–8, 2014|volume=36|issue=46|accessdate=September 29, 2014}}</ref>
In 2013, Brennan directed 10 episodes of ''[[Inside Amy Schumer]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2578508/fullcredits/|title=Inside Amy Schumer (TV Series 2013– )|publisher=|via=www.imdb.com}}</ref>
In 2015, Brennan developed and performed a comedy show, ''3 Mics,'' in Los Angeles. He brought it to New York City in 2016, opening on March 3 at the [[Lynn Redgrave Theater]]. It was directed by Drew Barr. John Legend and his Get Lifted partners, Mike Jackson and Ty Stiklorius, produced the limited engagement. The show has Brennan alternating among three microphones.<ref>[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/3-mics-neal-brennan-show-860362 Lee, Ashley] ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' (29 January 2016)</ref> At the first mic, he reads one-liners from index cards; at the second mic, he talks about dealing with depression and his relationship with his father; and at the third mic, he does traditional stand-up comedy.
In 2017, ''3 Mics'' was released as a Netflix original comedy special.
==Influences== Brennan has said that his comedy influences are [[Chris Rock]],<ref name=IFC/> [[Mort Sahl]],<ref name=IFC/> [[Dave Attell]],<ref name=CAREER/> [[Mike Royce]],<ref name=CAREER/> and [[David Juskow]].<ref name=CAREER/> ==Television work== *''[[Singled Out]]'', writer (1996) *''[[All That]]'', writer (1996–1997) *''[[Kenan & Kel]]'', writer (1997) *''[[Chappelle's Show]]'', creator, writer and director (2003–2004) *''[[Totally Awesome]]'', writer and director (2006) *''[[Attack of the Show|Attack of the Show!]]'', host (2012) *''[[The Approval Matrix]]'', host (2014–present) *''[[Inside Amy Schumer]]'', director (2013) *''[[The Daily Show with Trevor Noah]]'', contributor - "Trevor's friend" (2016—present)
==Filmography== *''[[Half Baked]]'', writer (1998) *''[[The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard]]'', director (2009) *''[[Get Him to the Greek]]'', actor (2010) * ''Neal Brennan: 3 Mics'', writer, director, performer (2017)
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://nealbrennan.com/}} * {{IMDb name|0107366}}
